SENT.plain: A 37-year-old female died of cerebral vasospasm as a complication of rewarming following hypothermia therapy for severe head injury
She presented with severe consciousness disturbance and anisocoria after falling down a flight of stairs
Computed tomography (CT) revealed a right acute subdural hematoma and temporal contusion
Following surgery, mild hypothermia was started and rewarming was completed by the 11th day
Neurological examination showed no abnormalities, but intracranial pressure (ICP) suddenly increased and she manifested anisocoria on the 13th day
Repeat CT revealed a low density area in the right middle cerebral artery region and cerebral angiography showed diffuse narrowing of the main arterial trunks
A cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample was collected using an intraventricular ICP monitoring catheter
The CSF level of 8-hydroxy-2'-deoxyguanosine was elevated during the rewarming period, indicating substantial deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) oxidation
She died on the 15th day due to uncontrollable ICP
Histological examination at autopsy of the narrowed artery found the waving phenomenon in the internal elastic lamina and invasion of inflammatory cells into the adventitia
These findings constitute the possible evidence that free-radical-mediated oxidative DNA damage may be important in the genesis of severe vasospasm due to rewarming following hypothermia
